reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s “long views win” / patient-values selection effect, claiming it may fail if lock-in happens before patient accumulators gain influence. This is only moderately central: it attacks one pro-convergence/pro-flourishing consideration in §2.3.3, not the essay’s main upshot (that WAM-convergence is unlikely and trade/compromise is the more promising route with many blockers). Strength is limited because the essay already explicitly notes the same timing objection (“might not have time to win out,” major decisions may be made soon), so the critique adds little new refutation beyond reframing it as a ‘quantitative cliff.’ The underlying point is largely correct (selection effects depend on relevant timescales/decision windows), though it somewhat mischaracterizes the essay as ‘assuming indefinite compounding’ or that such views ‘will dominate’—the essay presents it as a suggestive but non-decisive mechanism with caveats. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little-to-no dead weight.
title: Patient capital accumulation fails if lock-in occurs before dominance is achieved
